title: Eco veteran ‘Swampy’ hopes Extinction Rebellion can help ease climate emergency
text:
Daniel Hooper – aka Swampy – outside Haverfordwest Magistrates Court today (Picture Agency Ltd)

A veteran eco-warrior who made his name during a series of environmental campaigns in the 1990s has said the Extinction Rebellion (XR) protests give him ‘hope’.

Daniel Hooper, 46, who was known as ‘Swampy’, became a national figure after living underground for a week in a tunnel, to protest against the rerouting of the A30 in Devon.

Mr Hooper, who now lives in West Wales, was also involved in a series of high-profile environmental campaigns, targeting the M11, Newbury bypass and Manchester Airport.

He told ITV News: ‘My beliefs are the same as they always were and I did have a quiet 10 years, almost to the point where you have apathy towards how we can change things, then Extinction Rebellion started happening.

‘You think there is hope and I believe there is hope and now everyone need to think about what we are doing, governments needs to change, companies need to change.’

Swampy in one of the tunnels dug in the path of a planned expansion at Manchester airport. (Picture: Str Old)

Swampy reaches the surface on the new A30 road site at Fairmile, near Honiton, in January 1997 (Picture: PA Archive)

Some of the climate protesters who blocked access to the Valero refinery in Pembroke Dock, Wales, in September this year (Picture: Athena Picture Agency Ltd)

The environmental group returned to London yesterday, as part of two weeks of demonstrations worldwide to pressure governments to act on the climate crisis, following another prolonged period of activism in April.

Disruption continued today, with arrests now reaching the hundreds and the prime minister labelling activists ‘uncooperative crusties’.

‘Swampy’ added: ‘We need government action – they declared a climate emergency and since then pretty much nothing has happened. This is the most important issue of the day – more important than Brexit.’

‘We need People’s Assemblies to decide what to do, this is a state of emergency.’

Mr Hooper was speaking after earlier appearing before magistrates in Haverfordwest over an environmental protest last month.

He was fined £40 and ordered to pay £85 costs and a £32 surcharge after pleading guilty to wilful obstruction of a highway when he blocked a road to the Valero Pembroke Refinery during an XR action last month.

Demonstrators blocked three entrances to the site, which is one of the biggest oil refineries in Europe, on September 19, by attaching themselves to wooden boxes filled with concrete.

description: Daniel Hooper, known for living in a tunnel for a week during a 1990s protest, backs latest Extinction Rebellion protests.
